section.name: COMM BASED ENVIR HEALTH: Community Based Environmental Health

comments:
Community Based Environmental Health, an honors seminar offered in the spring, explored the effect of the environment on health.  The curriculum ranged from diverse topics such as household mold and second-hand smoke to cancer clusters and obesity.  The class was also an Academically-Based Community Service course that required community service in addition to class time.

The class involved a combination of lectures, guest speakers, readings, student presentations, discussions, research, and community service.  The students had two small research assignments with class presentations, including an Environmental and Health Policy Analysis and an Industrial Pollution Case Study Analysis, according to the course description. The major research assignment for the course was an environmental health topic of the student’s choosing, with recommendations for solving the problem based on the student’s research.

Students found the class to be fairly easy and extremely rewarding, providing “useful knowledge about the problems in the community and how to alleviate them.”  They especially enjoyed the “interesting” guest lecturers.  Students worked in groups and individually to research the environmental health topics.

Students thought Professor Pepino was “awesome,” “energetic,” and “inspiring.”  Several commented on his ability to stimulate interest in the subject matter.  As one student raved, “He really cares both about the subject matter and about his students.  One of the best teachers at Penn; take any course he offers even if you’re not interested.”  The only complaint was that Pepino was sometimes hard to get in touch with, or feedback was delayed.  Overall, however, he was rated highly for accessibility.
